ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

POLITICAL NEPOTISM
(Appointment of Commission of Inquiry)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister when will the Commission of Inquiry on Political Nepotism be appointed.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I refer the Member for Anson to my answer to the question of his on the 15th of January. I stated then that it would not be possible at any one time to have more than one High Court Judge available to conduct a Commission of Inquiry. It is the Government's intention to proceed with the first Commission of Inquiry as soon as a Judge is available. I have been informed by the Chief Justice that a Judge will be available towards the end of March or the beginning of April when another Judge On leave will be returning. Then the first Commission asked for by the

Column: 4

Member for Anson will be set up to inquire into the Secondary IV Examination boycott by some Chinese Middle School students, and to determine to what extent it was brought about by exploitation of students by Communists and their open front organisations.

    The second, and less important inquiry, is to investigate the events which developed into open insubordination and defiance of the Board of Management by some 130 out of 480 workers of the People's Association, and to establish the connection between these persons and their leaders who are members of the Barisan Sosialis who had been on the Board of Management.

    The third Commission is to inquire into all specific allegations of political nepotism and improper political interference with the Civil Service and employees of Statutory bodies, and to make recommendations provided that all Members who have voiced these allegations in the Assembly would undertake to repeat these allegations before the Commission and to give evidence of such allegations on oath or affirmation.

    A Commission will be set up as soon as a Commission on the first and second have been completed. The terms of reference will include, in the terms of the motions passed by this Assembly. all specific allegations made by Members of this Assembly in the course of that debate.

    My Secretary has written to all the Members who spoke on the debate asking them to indicate what allegations they have made which they would wish to have included in the terms of reference. So far no replies have been received except one from the Member for Anson.

    The Member for Anson appeared to have misunderstood the purport of the letter from my Secretary inviting him to mark out any or all of the specific allegations made in his speech on which he would give or tender evidence before the Commission so that these specific allegations could be included in the terms of reference. The Member for Anson wrote in his reply that it was for

Column: 5

the Commission to decide what the procedure should be. It is the duty of the Government, in accordance with the motion passed in this Assembly, with Members of the Barisan Sosialis voting against and the Member for Anson abstaining, to determine what the terms of reference of this Commission should be. Such terms of reference must set out the specific allegations that have been made.

    It is hoped that the Members concerned will indicate what specific allegations they have made which they are going to give evidence upon so that they could be included in the terms of reference.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, do I understand from the Prime Minister then that the Commission will not investigate any allegations from the public or any allegations other than those which were made in this House?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I have stated the position. The motion was as drafted in this Assembly and passed in this Assembly. It is now the duty of the government to implement the terms of the motion as set out in that particular debate. It is as simple as that.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, the motion that was passed was a motion of the Government, and it spoke of investigation of specific allegations. There was no question of investigation of specific allegations of Members of the Assembly. The question I am asking the Pr me Minister is whether it is Government's intention under the terms of reference to exclude investigation of specific allegations of corruption or improper conduct or nepotism which may come from the public.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, this was the point which the Member for Farrer Park made in the course of the debate. It was taken then because in the course of the debate anybody could voice any allegation, and any allegation voiced by a

Column: 6

Member in this Chamber would have to be repeated before the Commission. I am asking Members of this House who have made their allegations to mark out those passages in order that they be included in the terms of reference.

    Mr David Marshall: Only one more question. Sir. It does not arise out of the original question, but it was mentioned by the Prime Minister. I would inquire whether the second Commission he has in mind with reference to the People's Association would not incorporate in its terms of reference an investigation into the political activity and affiliation of the employees of the Association.

    The Prime Minister: There was considerable debate on this point, if I remember. I am speaking from memory now. In my reply to this particular question put by the Member for Anson, I dealt with the three points that arose. I think it was made quite clear that if there was to be a Commission of Inquiry, as was suggested by the Opposition - sorry, not by the Barisan Sosialis but by the Member for Anson, because I do not think the Barisan Sosialis were ever very keen on a Commission of Inquiry - it was to be an inquiry into the acts of insubordination of the 130 persons involved and their connection with the Barisan Sosialis. Those records are in the Hansard, and they hear witness to what transpired.

    Mr David Marshall: If I can satisfy the Prime Minister that, in fact, the issue sought by certain Members on this side of the House was an investigation into the political membership and activity of the People's Association, would he consider incorporating that as one of the terms of reference of that second Commission?

    The Prime Minister: If the Member for Anson can persuade me that any Member on this side of the House has made such a proposal or agreed to such a proposal, I will certainly do so. I will stand by what has transpired in the debate, whatever has been affirmed to and assented to by this side of the House.

CONSTITUTIONAL LAWYERS ASSISTING GOVERNMENT ON
PROPOSED CONSTITUTIONAL CHANGES


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he would indicate who are the Constitutional lawyers assisting Government with reference to the proposed constitutional changes.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I have been informed by the State Advocate-General that he has been in communication with the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Cambridge, Dr Ivor Jennings, and with Professor Wade and Professor Hood Phillips.

    Mr David Marshall: Are we to understand that, in fact, nobody has yet been appointed to assist the Government in these matters?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, as I have indicated in my reply to the last question, there is no question of appointing anybody to, as the word goes, assist the Government in these matters. When there are matters of constitutional difficulty arising in which the State Advocate-General considers that he requires expert advice, he has this panel to advise him. But it is the duty of the State Advocate-General's Chambers - persons properly qualified and constituted to discharge their duties and functions - to carry out the necessary statutory amendments which will he required.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, if you will permit me the Prime Minister informed this House on the 23rd January that the State Advocate-General was in correspondence with Constitutional lawyers of considerable experience who would be helping him, and was offering a contract to a Parliamentary draftsman to assist in the work of drafting. Would the Prime Minister inform us whether there has been any progress on those two aspects?

    The Prime Minister: That is exactly the point. Mr Speaker, Sir. Had the Member for Anson been kind enough to refer to or refreshed his memory on what was stated, he would have saved us this

Column: 8

unnecessary straying away from the point.

    There were two specific matters. One was legal advice, and I have named the persons with whom the State Advocate-General has been in touch. The other is the question of appointing a Parliamentary draftsman to do the actual work of drafting. Without having to mention the name of the draftsman, I would like to add that what has happened now is that the Attorney-General's Chambers in Kuala Lumpur has decided to engage this person under contract instead of the State Advocate-General's Chambers in Singapore.

    This Parliamentary draftsman of some experience was offered a contract by the Singapore Government, and I think he was also offered, either simultaneously or subsequently, a contract by the Federation Government. As I understand from the Attorney-General in the Federation, he has accepted the contract offered by the Federation Government.

    Mr David Marshall: Forgive me, Sir, do I understand that the position is this: that in respect of the proposed constitution, the only assistance the Government of Singapore will have will be a question of reference by the State Advocate-General to the Constitutional lawyers named, of the proposed sections and parts of the Constitution on which he will be seeking advice? Is that the position?

    The Prime Minister: The assumption made by the Member for Anson is that our State Advocate-General and his staff are somehow inadequate for their duties and that, therefore, somebody who really knows all about constitutional matters should be there to assist or to be really in charge of these duties. As I see the task before us, it is somewhat different from the experience of the Member for Anson. He decided in his own wisdom in 1956 to take an All-Party mission to London of some 13 Members of this Assembly. Whether or not it was the unlucky choice of numbers or for any other reason, the fact that the Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge University who is now in touch with the State Advocate-General, was

Column: 9

also there to advise him on the Constitution did not help him to succeed. Because it was not the business of the Constitutional lawyer to settle the Constitution. Constitutions are made by people who are supposed to know what is good for their own country. And we have reached basic agreement with the Federation as to the constitutional arrangements with the Federation. And the Constitutional lawyer comes in insofar as he is able to give effect to the intentions expressed by the two Governments. He is not there to try and create a constitution. He is there to implement one. And insofar as the State Advocate-General feels that he requires advice in respect of implementation of details, then he will seek that advice.

SINGAPORE HARBOUR BOARD
FIREMEN
(Conditions of Service)


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister to indicate (a) the average hours of work of firemen employed by the Singapore Harbour Board; (b) whether these firemen are required to perform duties other than fire-fighting duties; and (c) how do these conditions of service compare with those of firemen in other fire-fighting services in the State.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I propose to run briefly through the conditions of service, but I will also table it for the information of Members.

    The average hours -

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the answer is lengthy, the Prime Minister is perfectly at liberty to say that he will circulate the answer in the Official Report.

    The Prime Minister: I will summarise the oral reply to give the Member for Anson an opportunity to ask any further supplementary questions.

    Sir, the average hours of work a week of firemen employed by the Singapore Harbour Board are as follows:-

Column: 10



    For those on day duty-62 hours, in addition to which the men are required to be on stand-by for 28 hours.

    For those on night shift-42 hours, in addition to which the men are required to be on stand-by for 36 hours.

Firemen work alternative shifts each week.

    In addition to the normal fire-fighting duties, the Harbour Board firemen also carry out the following preventive duties:-

    (i) Salvage - operation of pumps, etc, when a vessel is in danger of sinking.

    (ii) Fire Watch - watch duty on board a vessel with dangerous cargo (e.g, chemicals).

    (iii)Watch Duty - watch duty on board ship when burning or welding operations are in progress.

    (iv) Oil Service - connect and disconnect pipes used in bunker or vegetable oil operations. Firemen working on this service are relieved of fire-fighting and other duties and work an 8-hour day.

    For purposes of comparison -

    (i) Firemen in the Singapore Fire Brigade work 56 to 60 hours a week, the actual hours being dependent upon the operation of the rota system, whilst those in the Airport Fire Service work an average of 60 hours a week.

    (ii) Firemen in the Singapore Fire Brigade perform the following duties in addition to fire-fighting duties:-

    (i) Rescue work in cases of jammed lifts.

    (ii) When the exigencies of the service permit, the firemen carry out other duties for members of the public on payment of a fee to the City Council, such as filling a swimming pool or covering a fire scene for a film. The

Column: 11

fees collected are not paid to them.

    (iii) Off-duty firemen are sent to do fire-watching duties at cinemas and at other public places of entertainment where it is considered necessary that a firemen should be in attendance. A fee of $3/- is charged for each duty period of 2 hours or part thereof. Half of this fee is paid to the firemen carrying out such work on off-duty hours.

Firemen in the Airport Fire Service also perform preventive duties such as attending refuellings, spillages (washing of apron of such spillage), defuellings, fuel flow tests, training flights, disposal of waste oil, and so on.

    Mr David Marshall: Is the Prime Minister aware, from the figures he has given, that with a day shift of 90 hours a week and a night shift of 78 hours a week, the Harbour Board Firemen do not have a single day's holiday in the week at all? Does he consider that appropriate, or would he consider seeking an amelioration of those conditions?

    The Prime Minister: These are matters which are looked after by the union. My own personal experience is that the firemen set out to form their own union sometime in 1956/1957 when a group of them broke away from the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association. It is now a matter for debate whether the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association or some other union which they formed represents the majority of the men. But whatever the position is, I would say that this is a subject matter for negotiation, and not for the Prime Minister really to apply his mind to each particular case to see whether it is just or unjust. I would like to point out, however, that 28 hours out of the 90 hours in the day shift and 36 hours out of the 78 hours in the night shift are stand-by duties, which means that a man should be

Column: 12

available in case there is an emergency. In other words, if he is going to a cinema, he should inform his family where he could be found. If he is going to visit an ailing aunt, he should make sure that somebody at home knows where the ailing aunt lives, and so on. If he is out with a guitar serenading by the quay-side, similarly it is expected that he will inform his friends where he can be found if needed for his other arduous duties. But everything said and done, what I would suggest as appropriate in this case is that if the men feel that conditions are too onerous, they have a union - they have two in fact - and representations can be made to the Board.

    Mr David Marshall: Do I understand from the Prime Minister, who is in charge of the Ministry into which the Harbour Board comes, that the representations should be made to him?

    The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson understands wrongly. I am not the employer of the men. The employer is the Singapore Harbour Board. There is a Chairman, there is a Board. It so happens that for ministerial purposes, it comes under my portfolio. But I think that the Member for Anson will appreciate that if I were to be in charge of all these other things, it might well be that I would wind up in a dizzy spin, as others who try to do as much often do wind up in dizzy spins.

GOVERNMENT POLICY ON "MASS GRAVES"
OF PEOPLE MASSACRED BY JAPANESE


    4. Mr Tee Kim Leng asked the Prime Minister whether the Government has adopted any policy regarding the reported discovery by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce of the "mass graves" of people said to have been massacred by the Japanese in early 1942.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, questions of war reparation, including compensation for atrocities and war damage, were the responsibility of the United Kingdom Government who in

Column: 13

1951 signed a treaty of peace with Japan. The Government has written to the U.K. Commission asking the U.K. Government to take up the matter with the Government of Japan to seek amends and atonement for the atrocities that they committed.

    The U.K. Commission has referred the matter to London and sought further information as to the scale of the present discovery of the intended remains. They have enquired whether the number of the persons involved may run to several thousands or something much less. They would like to know whether this evidence is related to some hitherto unrealised atrocities or of one already known. The U.K. Commission wrote to say that they believed that this recent discovery is evidence not of an atrocity as yet unknown but is connected with the massacres that had taken place, and were known to have taken place, though the actual sites of the graves may not have been known in detail.

    There are no reliable figures as to the total number of persons who were massacred by the Japanese invading forces in 1942. Some estimates put the figure around 10,000, and some much more, but certainly thousands of families have beloved ones who were missed shortly after the Japanese invasion. All of them were taken away from screening camps and were never heard of or seen again.

    While it may be difficult to ascertain the actual identity of the persons who had been massacred or their immediate dependents and families for compensation to be made direct, there is no doubt that the people of Singapore, as a whole, suffered by these massacres. It is our view that atonement should be made to the people of Singapore collectively.

    The Government is also considering the acquisition of the site where these bones have been discovered in order that a suitable memorial can be put up in, memory of the men who have been massacred. If the area is suitable, a green belt to provide for a small park may also be designated.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Japanese Government refuses to compensate for this reasonable request, then what steps will the Singapore Government take in the matter?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I need only point out that foreign affairs is in the hands of the British until independence through merger. I am quite sure the Barisan Sosialis now understands how stupid the proposal was that the next constitutional step for Singapore was full internal self-government with foreign -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am afraid that answer is completely out of order. I think that question is hypothetical anyway, and I must disallow it.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I just go on? I was on the point of going to the meat of the matter.

    Mr Speaker: I have disallowed the supplementary question as being hypothetical.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): A supplementary question.

    Mr Speaker: Tun Lim.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: The Minister for Finance was recently in Tokyo. He was there in all anxiety to foster good relationship with the Japanese Government and Japanese industrialists. May I ask the Prime Minister whether he did make use of the opportunity just to sound the Japanese Government about the cry of the people of Singapore when those bones were exhumed?

    The Prime Minister: I do not wish to prejudice private conversations on this matter, but I would like to say that the Japanese officials who were in contact with our officials and who happened to have been in Singapore previously fully appreciated the feelings on this matter. I think they may be more than prepared to make some atonement for the atrocities that had been committed.

NEW POWER STATION


    5. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Prime Minister (a) whether Government intends to build another power station in view of the proposed industrialization, and (b) whether he would name the site of the station.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I would refer the Member for Mountbatten to my reply to her colleague, the Member for Tanglin, at the sitting of this House on 15th January, 1962, when he expressed his fears of future blackouts. I then said:

    `A new power station to meet the needs of industrial expansion is also being built and a World Bank loan is being sought for this. The consultants for this project are already in Singapore.

    The first Phase of the new station is for plant capable of generating 60 M.W. which is scheduled for commission in 1965. With these developments, it is not expected that there will be any sudden shortage of supply in the future. On the contrary, our total generating plant, once installed, should enable us to meet our expanding needs, including the Jurong Industrial Development project.'

    The new power station will be sited on land adjacent to the existing Pasir Panjang Power Station. Consideration is also being given to another extension to the existing station.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it true that if this new proposed power station is built at Pasir Panjang, to take it to Jurong would cost over $7 million?

    The Prime Minister: Can I have the actual meaning of the expression "to take it to Jurong"? To take the power to Jurong, or to take the station to Jurong?

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: To bring the power to Jurong, Mr Speaker.

    The Prime Minister: I would not like to embark on minute subsidiaries of this nature, because I do not think the consideration of the site is influenced only by the cost of laying cables from Pasir Panjang to Jurong. There must be certain other factors, such as proximity to the present site for management purposes and so on, which bear heavily on these questions. I am not in a position to give an expert opinion

Column: 16

on these things. If the Member for Mountbatten feels that she has been sufficiently advised or briefed to question the propriety of the sitting of the site, perhaps notice could be given, and I would be properly advised on the matter.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I just wonder whether the Prime Minister is aware of the fact that there is an oil company next to the station which has made me raise these questions. If ever there is a leakage of oil coming up to the surface and should there be a fire, and if the centralisation of this station is at Pasir Panjang, then the whole of Singapore, including industries, will not have electricity. Has the Prime Minister given consideration to that fact, and having given consideration to that fact, does he not think that it would be cheaper in the long run to have an entirely new station at Jurong - as other more developed countries are doing decentralising their power stations?

    The Prime Minister: With respect to the hon. Lady, that is an entirely different factor altogether. As I see it, the first question is related to the cost of taking power from Pasir Panjang to Jurong. Now an additional argument is put forward, that perhaps, to site one power station next to another is bad, and in any case the position is further made worse because an oil company is nearby. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not in a position to answer each of these questions in specificatio. As I have said, if she will put them down specifically, I will give the expert's answers to them.

    But I will make this one point, Sir. Before the oil company was allowed at its present site, all the experts had been consulted and all the necessary rules and regulations had been complied with to the satisfaction of the experts as far as fire was concerned. On that score, I can, from my personal recollection of what took place in the negotiations, assure the hon. Lady that there is a minimum of risk arising out of fire. I am in fact, assured by the authorities

Column: 17

concerned that the risk is not to the Pasir Panjang Power Station. If the risk is a risk to any important installation, it is the harbour and the anchorage.

CENTRAL BODY OF TRADE UNIONS


    6. Tun Lim Yew Hock asked the Minister for Labour (a) whether any central body of trade unions is recognised by the Government as representing trade union interests in Singapore; (b) what is the name of such body; and (c) what is the number of unions affiliated to it.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to question (a) is no. That being so, questions (b) and (c) require no answer. At a later date when the position has been clarified the Government will give consideration to this matter.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether the T.U.C. is still a registered trade union?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as the record of the T.U.C, is concerned, it has been announced that it has been dissolved because of the split between two groups of unions on political issues.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, what I am asking is whether, according to the records of the Labour Department, the T.U.C, is still a registered trade union?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Then, can I ask the Parliamentary Secretary by what strange process the T.U.C., which has been recognised as a central body to represent trade unions in Singapore, is now no longer recognised when it is still in existence?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Cairnhill knows very well that the T.U.C, was, during his time, run by him and was in existence on the register, but there were no

Column: 18

activities at all on the premises of the T.U.C. So, similarly, after the split in the T.U.C., it goes back to the same position, which means that there is no activity now in the T.U.C.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: The Parliamentary Secretary is avoiding the question. What I say is, if it was recognised before by the P.A.P., why is it not recognised now? Will he please remember that in the Industrial Relations Ordinance, the T.U.C. is the body to nominate members to the employees' panel? Does he realise that? If the T.U.C. is no longer recognised, then the Industrial Relations Ordinance must be amended.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the position will be clarified as it develops day by day. But, anyway, in the Industrial Relations Ordinance, there is provision too that the Minister has the power to nominate persons to become members of the panel.

OCCUPIERS AND TERMS OF TENANCY
OF FORMER NANTINA HOME


    7. Tun Lim Yew Hock asked the Minister for Labour who are the present occupiers of the former Nantina Home in Queen Street, what are the terms of the tenancy and the reasons for granting such tenancy.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker. Sir, the present occupiers of the' former Nantina Home in Queen Street are:

    The Singapore National Seamen's Union;

    The Singapore Insurance Companies Employees' Union;

    The Singapore Bank Employees' Union;

    The Musicians' Union of Singapore;

    The Amalgamated Union of Public Employees; and

    The United Workers of Petroleum Industry.

    No terms of tenancy were entered into by Government with the occupiers of Trade Union House (Nantina Home),

Column: 19

which was made available to the then Trades Union Congress free of rent as a temporary measure until such time as the new Trade Union House has been built. This is in accordance with the election programme of the Government to build a Trade Union House to serve as a Central Headquarters for all trade unions in Singapore. The long-term plans to provide a new Trade Union House at Shenton Way are well advanced. The new building on this site will be known as the Singapore Conference Hall-cum-Trade Union House. It will serve as a venue for the holding of international conferences and other Government functions of a like nature, besides providing all the amenities of a Central Headquarters for the trade unions in Singapore.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, all the trade unions mentioned by the Parliamentary Secretary are trade unions under the control of the P.A.P. -

    Mr David Marshall: Naturally.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: - and to allow, those unions to make use of the Nantina -
